data.title: Refactor ShapeInfo to Introduce a Base Class for Vertex-Based Shapes

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

As described in [this comment](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/54#issuecomment-223836154) of issue #54, it would be highly beneficial to unify Poly-, Loop- and ChainShapes to a single common base class for vertex-based shapes.
#### Analysis
- Potential properties: `Vertices`, `MaxVertexCount`, `IsLoop` and `IsSolid`.
- Places that could benefit from this are `RigidBodyShapeCamViewLayer`, `RigidBodyRenderer` and `RigidBodyEditor`.
- Since this is a breaking change anyway, it would be worth considering to get rid of `LoopShape` and instead express it as an `IsLoop` property of `ChainShape`.

data.title: Physics Support for Chain Shapes

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Duality currently supports Circle-, Polygon- and Loop Shapes. There is no way to specify a shape that is not a closed loop, which can be unwieldy at times and also gets in the way of issue #279. Extend the physics backend and Duality glue code to support Chain Shapes to fix this.
#### Analysis
- The Farseer Physics backend currently does not support Chain Shapes, but Farseer 3.5 does. It is likely that Chain Shape support could be merged into the Duality-specific version of Farseer, potentially replacing the Loop Shape entirely.
- A Loop Shape is actually a special case of a Chain Shape. The physics backend might only need support for the chain shape case, while the Duality glue code could use it in one or the other way.
- There needs to be editor support for Chain Shapes. It is likely that this could share a lot of code with Loop Shape editing.
#### Next Steps
- [x] Merge back ChainShape to Farseer backend, replacing LoopShape.
- [x] Update Duality to internally use the physics ChainShape for creating LoopShapes.
- [x] Introduce a new ChainShape type to Duality.
- [x] Implement editor support for ChainShapes.

data.title: Investigate the Potential Unification of Serialization and Cloning

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: New systems and modules requiring a significant amount of long-term effort.

data.body:
#### Summary

Cloning and Serialization are closely related systems, yet the co-exist distinctly and introduce technical debt while preventing certain optimizations from being equally useful in both cases. Investigate (once again) whether it would be viable to unify them.
#### Analysis
- The main reason the cloning system exists are:
  - Ability to target an existing object graph.
  - Ownership analysis, e.g. not dragging _everything_ into the cloning / serialization graph, but determining exactly what is required.
- Given the above points, the cloning system could be interpreted as a feature-wise superset of serialization. Can the findings and algorithms from cloning be used to improve serialization to the point that it can replace cloning entirely?
- The complete set of Cloning system unit tests could be kept to verify cloning-via-serialization still works as expected. Some corner cases might fail, which will have to be re-investigated for their severity.
- Performance in general will be an important consideration.
  - Cloning doesn't require metadata like (version-safe) serialization does. A special serializer would likely be required to achieve comparable performance. On the plus side, that same serializer could then also be used for regular serialization in game releases, where versioning and source control safety is no longer that big of a concern.
  - Still, serialization performs one step that cloning technically doesn't need: Writing everything into a stream and parsing it again later. For Prefabs, the main use case, this could be eased by caching the intermediate stream after loading.
  - On the plus side, cloning might also become a bit simpler with that stream as a clear separation line in the middle. No explicit object mapping, etc.
  - The again, serialization could also become slower due to the fact that it would now, being unified, require ownership detection and become a two-step process as well. The ownership analysis won't create object instances though, but instead map objects to serialization IDs.

It might be a good idea to not approach this unless triggered by a specific need or task complex. Cloning and serialization are both stable right now. "Never change a running system."

data.title: Reduce Struct Array Serialization Verbosity

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

In the course of issue #279, it became apparent that both XML and Binary serialization write a lot of unnecessary information when serializing a large amount of structs. Investigate ways to reduce the amount of written data in the case of struct and struct array serialization.
#### Analysis
- While `null` values can be serialized easily, there currently is no special case for `default(T)` struct values. They could be omitted safely just as well.
  - `XmlSerializer`: Just don't populate the current struct element in `WriteStruct`.
  - `BinarySerializer`: Use the skip-field array to skip all fields.
  - Be careful with regard to surrogate and custom serialization.
  - Investigate: Could this be implemented in the same spot where reference types are checked for null?
- Theoretically, this could be extended towards omitting `default(T)` fields of a struct value.
  - Doesn't work for classes, as they can have arbitrary constructors, so their field's default is unknown.
  - May result in less readable XML. Could be considered for binary serialization.
- Add unit tests that check specifically for potential problems with the omission of values.
#### Attachments

Sample excerpt of verbose XML struct array serialization:

data.title: Cleanup the Logging System

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

The logging system is mostly fine right now, but its API is also the result of organic growth. Use the v3.0 major version step as an opportunity to cleanup and refactor the public API, as well as make some overdue changes to its internals.
#### Analysis
- Log formatting methods could move into a distinct static `LogFormat` class.
- Default logs could be moved to a static `Logs` class, making `Log` a completely non-static class.
- Provide an easy way to introduce custom global logs, maybe using a generic `Logs.Get<T>` interface using static generic class storage internally.
- Make indentation a property of log outputs, rather than logs or log entries, get rid of `SharedState`.
  - Could be expressed as `ILogOutput` Push / Pop indentation API.
- `LogEntry` should not contain `source` log or `context` references. Consider making them part of the `ILogOutput` API instead.
  - For editor support, remove the core `InMemoryLogOutput` and replace it with an editor-specific log output that also stores source log and context information in addition to the `LogEntry`. 
  - That way, core logs will be strictly serializable and more lightweight, while the editor can add as much diagnostic info as it wants.
- Unify visual and text logging APIs, or at least make sure they're similar enough so they don't require their own "learning curve".
- Use UTC Timestamps, update LogView to convert them back to local time.
- Make `Log` and `ILogOutput` implementations thread-safe, if they aren't yet.

data.title: Reduce Render Pipeline Bureaucracy

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

Investigate where the render pipeline could be improved with regard to reducing virtual method calls, class (vs. struct) usage and overall OOP chit-chat.
#### Analysis
- This will require a reliable rendering benchmark with a lot of objects. _Edit:_ Moved the details to issue #549.
- **Each `ICmpRenderer` has its own `IsVisible` call.** 95% of them just check for the visibility groups and / or the screen overlay flag being set, followed by checking if they're in bound-radius range of the viewport.
  - Would it be an improvement to instead just expose a group filter flags property and do all the group and radius-culling checks in a tight loop inside the render pipeline?
  - Every interface API usage is a virtual call. Reduce them to an absolute minimum.
    - `ICmpRenderer.GetCullingData` out-returns a struct with all information required to decide whether it will be visible to a device or not. Can be invoked to directly write into some internal RawList array store, which can then be batch-processed easily.
    - Bonus: `GetCullingData` only needs to be called once per frame per object and its results can be re-used by every camera and rendering pass.
    - `ICmpRenderer.Draw` does the rendering like it does right now.
- **There are a lot of interface calls involved.** See if it is possible to get rid of some of them, or transform per-object calls to one "group" call for N objects.
  - In general, prefer one call with N objects over N calls for each object individually.
- **CalcZOffset takes a lot of time for large vertex arrays** and could be avoided entirely.
  - Tilemaps and similar renderers can sometimes submit thousands of vertices. Calculating the depth offset of 4096 vertices takes about 0.1 ms, which isn't critical, but very unfortunate, given its redundant nature.
  - Most of the time, the renderer has a perfectly clear idea of the representative Z offset of a submitted drawbatch. Why not provide the API to specify it?
  - When not specifying it, `CalcZOffset` could be used as a fallback.
- **Don't sacrifice usability on the game side.**
  - `ICmpRenderer` should still act "per-object" and expose one draw method per object.
  - However, it would be possible to introduce an optional `ICmpMultiRenderer` interface where one draw method is called with an array of all queried objects of the matching type is provided. 
    - If there is a significant performance improvement, this could be a neat middle ground between having a full "grouped Component" and having one Component per object.
    - ~~With the multi-renderer interface in mind, it might make sense to also refactor the `IRendererVisibilityStrategy` interface, so the query method actually provides guaranteed type-sorted renderer arrays / RawLists in some form.~~
      - ~~Keep the overhead low. Potentially even keep the "exposed RawList" approach, but enforce specifying "type sections" inside that list.~~
    - ~~_If_ this shows a notable improvement (yet to be shown), we could also go a similar route for updates and provide a matching `ICmpMultiUpdatable` interface.~~
- etc. / investigate

data.title: Provide UV Offset Values as a per-Texture Material Property

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

As described [here](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=812), there is currently no easy and convenient way to assign a UV offset to a texture.
#### Analysis
- While this could be done as a per-Renderer property that adjusts vertex generation, a preferable way seems to be having an additional Material property per-Texture. (Multitexturing, shared among different renderers, etc.)
- This could be achieved by providing the appropriate uniforms in the default shader and evaluating them during vertex processing.
- For custom shader support, this feature should also be provided as part of a potential shared "shader library".
- With regard to this, issues #219 and #220 are closely related.

data.title: FileEventManager Events Should be Multi-File Events

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

Currently, the global file system watcher events in the `FileEventManager` class deal with one path at a time. This severely limits scalability performance-wise. Instead, each of those events should deal with N files, and the `FileEventManager` should internally aggregate N consecutive events of the same kind to a single event.
#### How to reproduce
- Import 500 icons into the project and watch as the Project View updates for each added one individually. 
- Delete the 500 Resources and watch as it updates for each removed one individually.
#### Analysis
- There are cases where the order of events matters, so it will be important to not blindly aggregate all events of the same type, but to batch only _sequences_ of events of the same type.

data.title: Move Font Import Data to Import Parameters

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Currently, the `Font` Resource contains a lot of data and logic that is only relevant in the specific case of importing a TTF font and adjusting it in the editor. After #285, #321 and #320 are implemented, do a general cleanup of the existing Font Resource and importer. 
#### Analysis
- `EmbeddedTrueTypeFont` is no longer required, as the source file is used directly. It's a proper Re-Import after all.
- `Size` can become a readonly FYI property similar to `Height`.
- `CharSpacing` can be moved to the importer.
- `MonoSpace` logic can be implemented in the importer while only providing FYI data in the core.
- `Style` can be moved to the importer.
- `GlyphsDirty` can be removed.
- When possible, make this backwards compatible.
  - Providing a one-click fix using a Re-Import could be considered a sufficient exception.
  - Breaking binary plugins would not be acceptable. Removing properties or property setters will likely do so.
  - Consider adding an obsolete attribute to them, document them accordingly, and later move this issue to the v3.0 milestone.

data.title: Implement an AssetInfo PropertyEditor with ReImport Functionality

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

After #285 is implemented, there needs to be a way to edit custom data attachments of a Resource in the editor and perform a re-import with the updated values. A special `PropertyEditor` can be implemented to do this and displayed when selecting a Resource where a Re-Import is possible.
#### Analysis
- Only needs to edit existing key-value pairs, no need to provide the ability to add or remove them.
  - Could just behave like editing any regular object instance.
- For the `PropertyEditor`, an invisible parent editor could host both `ResourcePropertyEditor` and the associated `AssetInfoPropertyEditor`.
  - Make sure to not break any caching mechanism and keep editor re-usage working.
- There should be a Re-Import button at the end.
  - This could actually be displayed whenever a Re-Import is possible, regardless of the availability of custom data attachments / import settings.
- There could be an Export button at the end as well, though this would be optional.
- If a re-import or export operation is performed, the `AssetInfoPropertyEditor` needs to check for new and / or removed key-value pairs.
  - Re-Import operations already [trigger editor-wide PropertyChanged events](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/master/DualityEditor/AssetManagement/AssetManager.cs#L145), which will result in the Object Inspector doing an update.
  - Export operations don't do this. The AssetInfo editor will need to keep track of this by itself somehow. Potentially add editor infrastructure for getting notified of AssetManager operations?

data.title: Improve Source / Resource File Mapping in AssetManagement

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Right now, the AssetManagement system performs a simulated export on a Resource in order to determine which source files belong to it. However, not all importers (can, should or do) specify an export method, and not in all cases this export is symmetrical with regard to a previous import.
#### Analysis
- Don't rely on simulated export.
- Introduce a distinct way to determine which `Source/Media` files belong to a given Resource.
  - A combination of AssetManagement API and data attachment hints could do the trick.
  - Attaching a source file name hint per-Resource could be done at [this](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/master/DualityEditor/AssetManagement/Import/AssetImportOperation.cs#L204-L214) part of an `AssetImportOperation`.
  - Hint file paths should be relative to the [directory of the Resource when mapped to `Source/Media`](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/master/DualityEditor/AssetManagement/AssetManager.cs#L121-L129), so they don't need to be updated when moving the Resource around.
  - Renaming a Resource would require to rename these hints as well, along with the existing `Source/Media` files that are already synced / renamed anyway, see [here](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/master/DualityEditor/FileEventManager.cs#L487-L503).
  - Will need to load and save the affected Resource, but since renaming requires selecting it first, it's likely already loaded and ready to be saved.
- The existing simulated export can still serve as a fallback when there is no mapping data available as part of the AssetInfo.
- Existing Export-Edit-ReImport workflow remains unaffected, since file change events trigger ReImport in a way that resolves the affected Resource by querying available importers, which don't care about hints regarding previous imports. The new import operation will overwrite previous hints automatically, so no explicit syncing is required either.
- Look into code a little more to figure out the details.

data.title: Allow to Pass Temporary per-Operation Data From AssetImporter Prepare to Import

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

As described in [this comment](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/285#issuecomment-213997774) from issue #285, there are cases where the preparation step of an importer already needs to parse some of the imported files in order to figure out which source files will be used. The import step then needs to do the parsing again, because there is no way to pass data from preparation to import.
#### Analysis
- The passed data should be temporary, no serialization.
- While it would technically be sufficient to allow passing a single tag-like object along, it might be a good idea to do a symmetrical API as in custom data attachments (issue #285) for developer convenience.
- Contrary to this, it might be a good idea to make a conscious distinction between the persistent data attachment API and the purely temporary per-operation data for the active importer.

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

#### Summary

When manually deleting an installed package's source code / project files, uninstalling that package will lead to a crash when applying the update. This is likely a minor bug in [DualityUpdater](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/tree/master/DualityUpdater).

- Install a package that includes source code. Shutdown the editor.
- Manually remove all the source code files.

- Alternatively, deleting the `ApplyUpdate.xml` file after uninstalling the package will work around the crash.

data.title: Tilemap Editor: Depth Offset Editing

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

While technically implemented, there is currently no way to access and edit per-Tile depth offsets from the editor. This should be changed in the long run, so depth can be tweaked easily.
#### Analysis
- Depth offset editing can probably be implemented as a (single?) new `TilemapTool`.
- A usable and cheap way to edit depth would be like the one implemented in the Tileset editor.
  - Left Mouse increases height.
  - Right mouse decreases height.
  - Holding each button and moving over different tiles will assign the same (updated) value to them.
  - Editing like this favors small local tweaks over large scale editing.
- It remains questionable whether other tools (rect, fill) are required for depth editing, but it seems like a safe bet to leave them out in a first implementation and extend when required later.
- There also should be a way to visualize the depth offsets of each tile.
  - Introduce a new `CamViewLayer` for this, which can be activated manually, but is automatically activated while using the depth `TilemapTool` and deactivated later.
  - Color coding seems to be a good way to approach this.

data.title: Refactor Editor CamView Overlay Rendering (Z-Offsets)

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

As emerging with the Tilemaps editor progress, some of the interaction indicators drawn by the editor use their target object's Z value as a basis for their own depth offset, assuming a "Z-flat" object. This is not true in all cases and will lead to editing looking broken when interacting with objects that do not submit to this assumption. `ActorRenderer` from issue #282 is a good example.
#### Analysis
- Part of the problem is that an object's Z position is no longer representative of its submitted vertices' Z positions due to custom Z offsets.
- Reconsider which indicators really should be drawn in world space and which should be drawn as a camera overlay.
- Move the indicator drawing code around to fit the new scheme, most likely from world space to camera overlay.

data.title: ObjectPropertyChangedEventArgs.HasProperty shouldn't always return true on CompleteChange

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

The current implementation of `ObjectPropertyChangedEventArgs.HasProperty` and `HasAnyProperty` always returns true if `CompleteChange` is true, even if no object that can contain the property is part of the change event. 

This can lead to performance problems in the editor and does so in the Tilemaps plugin when the Tileset editor is open.
#### How to reproduce
- Start the Tilemaps Sample.
- Open the Tileset editor.
- Open the sample Scene and create a SpriteRenderer.
- Select the Tileset in the Project View.
- Move around the SpriteRenderer. This triggers a complete Tileset Invalidation.
#### Notes
- Before changing behavior, evaluate all `HasProperty` and `HasAnyProperty` callsites for potential side effects.
- Consider removing the `string` overloads of the aforementioned methods, or at least flagging them as obsolete.

data.title: Redirect Child Window Command Keys

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

When undocking a docking control from the main window so it becomes a child window, global commands like `Ctrl + Z` can only be triggered when the main window has focus. The child window does not redirect menu commands back to the main window when unused.
#### Analysis
- This will require more research in order to find out...
  - ...a good way to redirect these commands.
  - ...whether or not they are required in the child window, so no redirect is performed in that case.
  - ...whether there are any existing solutions for the DockPanel suite. There has been a bit of development since Duality forked from it. Maybe file an issue there?
#### Attachments
- [StackOverflow Answer](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6078366/c-sharp-system-windows-forms-keys-how-to-keep-application-hotkeys-in-one-pla) to a similar topic.
- [DockPanel Suite](https://github.com/dockpanelsuite/dockpanelsuite) on GitHub.

data.title: Unify Renderer Depth Offsets

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
#### Summary

Right now, there is the `Offset` property in SpriteRenderers which specifies a somewhat abstract int value that allows to add a depth offset to the sprite. The exact scale of this offset is inaccessible, however. This is impractical and unnecessarily hides information from the end user while at the same time making it harder to interact with other Components that might choose different internal offset scales.

Instead, there should be a unified way to specify renderer depth offsets in Duality.
#### Analysis
- An easy solution would be to switch to exact depth offsets that will be added to each vertex as-is.
- There could even be a `SerializeErrorHandler` that fixes old renderers to prevent breaking backwards compatibility.

data.title: Allow Users to Specify Update / Init Order of Components

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Currently, Components are updated by Type, but the actual order of the Types is non-deterministic. Instead, derive the update order from Component requirement attributes and consider allowing a user attribute for changing update order of certain Components globally or relative to each other.
#### Analysis
- This would help with some edge cases of Component init or update dependencies.
- See also: [Component Init-By-Type](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/303)
